entry.title: Display of the Number of Goals per User in People Analytics Story Reporting
entry.content:
A typical requirement in talent management reporting is to show the number of employees according to the number of goals, i.e. performance goals or development goals. Such a chart could help to identify employees which have not yet defined any goals, or also employees which have too many or too less goals. In this blogpost alternative approaches are presented to realize such a reporting requirement in People Analytics Story Reporting.

Introduction

An important HR requirement in talent management is to identify employees which have not yet defined any goals, or also employees which have too many or too less goals. See left side in Figure 1 which shows

  • Total number of considered employees
  • Total number of Objective plans which is the number of combinations of employees and objective plans (e.g. if one employee has goals in 3 of the selected objective plans, then the number “3” is considered; if an employee has goals in a single objective plan or also in none of the selected objective plans, then the number “1” is considered)
  • Total number of Goals (e.g. if an employee has 3 goals in ‘objective plan A’ and 5 goals in ‘objective plan B’, then the number “8” is considered)
  • Number of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan, i.e. which is just the “Total number of Goals” divided by the “Total Number of  Objective Plans”

The chart in Figure 1 shows the “Total Number of Objective Plans“ according to the number of goals. You can see that there are 1229 employees which don’t have any goals in one of the selected objective plans, 28 employees with a single goal in the selected objective plans, 11 employees with 2 goals and so on.

 Figure 1   'Histogram' (more precise, 'chart of type "Bar/Column") to show the number of employees per number of goals

Solution Approach

In the following the different steps are explained how to create a query and the respective story to derive the chart as it is shown in Figure 1.

1. Query creation

Create the query as shown in Figure 2. Note that:

  • The object “Primary Objective Fields” from “All Templates” in schema “Objective Management” is used. This was chosen to allow the possibility to select one or multiple bonus plans as indicated in Figure 1 on the right.
  • The anchor of the query is “Basic User Information” from schema “User”. It is also possible to create the query the other way round. However, only when having "Basic User Information" as anchor it is possible to derive also the employees without any goal plans and goals.

Select at least fields like employee name, user ID, objective plan ID, objective plan name and goal. You might add also filters e.g. to consider only goal plans in status “completed”, “on track” but to ignore goal plans in status “Cancelled” or “Postponed”.

Figure 2   Query based on “All Templates” within schema “Objective Management”

2. Story measure calculations

Create the following 4 story calculations as indicated in Figure 3, 4, 5 and 6.

To illustrate the necessity to calculate the “Total Number of Objective Plans” let’s consider the following example: Assume there are 100 employees for “goal plan 2023” and 120 employees for “goal plan 2024”. Further assume you run the report for both bonus plans. Then the number of employees is 120 (under the assumption that the 100 employees of “goal plan 2023” are among the employees relevant for “goal plan 2024”). This is derived with the calculated measure “Employees” as shown in Figure 3. However, more important for our report is the combination of employees and goal plans which is 220 (=100 + 120). This is derived with the calculated measure “Total Number of Objective Plans” as shown in Figure 4.

Figure 3   Story calculation of type ‘Aggregation’ to derive the number of employees

Figure 4   Story calculation of type ‘Aggregation’ to derive the total number of objective plans

The next calculation is the overall number of “goals”. Let’s stick at the example from above; let’s assume that the 100 employees maintained in objective plan “goal plan 2023” overall 400 goals and that the 120 employees maintained in objective plan “goal plan 2024” overall 590 goals. Here, it could be possible that one goal as e.g. “Improve my leadership skills” is for some of the employees part of “goal plan 2023” as well as part of “goal plan 2024”. Nevertheless, the combination of employees and goal plans is 990 (=400 + 590). This is derived with the calculated measure “Total Number of Goals” as shown in Figure 5. To derive the “Number of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan” it is now just required to divide the “Total number of goals” and “Total Number of Objective Plans”. For the example here, this would be an average number of 4,5 goals (=990 / 220).

Figure 5   Story calculation of type ‘Aggregation’ to derive the number of goals

Figure 6   Story calculation of type ‘Calculated Measure’ to derive the quotient between “Number of Goals” and “Total Number  of Objective Plans”

 3. Story Dimension Calculation

The final calculation step is transforming the “Number of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan” into a dimension. It is important to consider the “Dimension Context”: Our use case is to show the Number of Goals per Employee and Objective Plan. Therefore, the dimension context is the employee (i.e. the field ‘User ID’) and the goal plan (i.e. ‘objective plan ID’). Here, the bit ‘tricky’ part is to find meaningful ‘goal ranges’ (i.e. ‘Member Name’) so that the visual representation results in a chart that basically resembles a Gaussian distribution (see Figure 7). Furthermore, it is recommended to provide a counter as prefix to the ’Member Name’ (i.e. (1), (2), (3), ….), so that the sorting works properly (if this ‘prefix would be missing, in the sample provided here the sorting would be “1 Goal”, “13-15 Goals”, “16 and More Goals”, “2 Goals”, “3 Goals”, ….).

Figure 7   Story calculation of type ‘Measure-Based Dimension’ to convert the “Number of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan”

4. Chart Creation

Finally, it is possible to create a visual presentation of the previously calculated figures. Figure 8 shows a “Bar/Column” chart with the measure “Total Number of Objective Plans” and dimension “Goal Ranges”.

Figure 8   Bar chart with measure ‘Total Number of Objective Plans’ and dimension ‘Goal Ranges’

5. Further remarks:

  • Of course, the presented approach works not only for goals/objective data but also for (1) any similar (e.g. performance form data) or (2) also slightly different use cases (e.g. number of particular benefits rolled out/claimed per employee).
  • Instead of manual definition of “Member Names” as shown in Figure 7 you could also tick “Use measure values as dimension members”. However, in addition to the shortcomings described above (1. no Gaussian distribution; 2. confusing sorting), ‘members’ without any ‘Goals per Employee/Objective Plan’ would not show up in the Bar Chart.
  • It is also possible to use a chart of type “Histogram”. Use “Total Number of Goals” as ‘Measure’ and “User ID” and "Objective Plan ID" as ‘Aggregation Dimension’. Then, you have to adjust the ‘Chart Properties’. It is not recommended to switch off ‘Automatically Set Range of Values’: With this option you would probably generate odd ranges. However, for the use case of goals it is recommended to use fixed ranges as e.g. “14” as “’Number of bins’ and “1” and “15” as ‘Minimum’/’Maximum’ (important: choose 'Number of Bins' plus "1" for the 'Maximum'; only then each range covers the range of "1.00"). As shown in Figure 9 this approach works also fine (compare numbers from Figure 1 with numbers of Figure 9). 
    Advantage: This approach is faster to implement; only "Total Number of Goals" (see Figure 5) needs to be created
    Disadvantage: (a) The case of employees without any goal (see 1st column of 1229 employees/goal plans without any goal defined) is missing and (b) Less flexibility regarding the definition of 'Goal Ranges' (in particular to define something like "More than 16 goals)"
    Therefore, the approach which is previously described is more recommended.

 Figure 9   Chart of type "Histogram" to show the number of goals per employee/objective plan

entry.title: Clean Core by Design: Using SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) as the First Principle
entry.content:
In the digital era of today where digital transformation is every organization’s need, SAP Clean Core Principle is more than just a word, it's a among the foundational principle for enterprises looking to future-proof their SAP landscape. As per the SAP clean core approach, where technology is moving towards API first Approach, modular architectures, the organizations must decouple their custom logic instead of the application server to external API’s outside the application server layer to ensure agility, scalability, and reducing the upgrade complexity.

One of the most powerful enablers of this Clean Core approach is the event driven architecture through SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), an enterprise-grade event brokering solution that supports real-time, event-driven architectures across hybrid landscapes.

In this blog, I’ll walk you through how to achieve Clean Core by adopting AEM as the first principle, laying the groundwork for a decoupled, scalable, and intelligent enterprise.

 The Clean Core Strategy — What and Why?

  1. Avoid Extensions where not required
  2. Upgrades should not interfere with the extensions and extensions should not interfere with the upgrades
  3. Decouple the extensions from the Standard
  4. Keep the custom code separate from the S4 Core

A Clean Code

The Clean Core strategy focuses on:

  • Keeping custom code, extensions, and integrations outside the SAP S/4HANA digital core.
  • Leveraging side-by-side extensibility using SAP BTP.
  • Using stable APIs and events to communicate between systems and layers.

This approach ensures that your core ERP remains clean, lean, and easily upgradeable—an essential factor for reducing TCO and accelerating innovation cycles.

In short, minimize extensions, decouple them from the standard, build side-by-side extensions on the BTP layer without touching the S4 HANA Core.

 Why AEM as the First Principle?

To achieve the clean core strategy, event driven architecture plays an important role by decoupling the processes through individual events, following the loosely couple framework and avoiding tightly coupled integrations.

SAP Advanced Event Mesh enables event-driven architecture (EDA) that decouples the source of truth (S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, C4C, etc.) from consumers (external apps, extensions, APIs). Here's why it's foundational to Clean Core:

  • Asynchronous Communication: No tight coupling between systems.
  • Loose Integration: Replace point-to-point interfaces with publish-subscribe models.
  • Extensibility: Let consumers build side-by-side extensions without modifying the core.
  • Scalability: Support multiple consumers with minimal configuration overhead.

 Clean Core in Action — Event-Driven Architecture with AEM

Let’s take a simple example: BP Onboarding in SAP S/4.

 Without Clean Core (Tightly Coupled):

  1. Custom ABAP enhancements in S/4HANA to trigger BP Creation/ Change Events.
  2. Direct API calls or IDoc triggers to downstream applications like ARIBA/ C4C/ Hybris/ External Applications from S/4.
  3. Every new consumer or change = new code or regression testing.

 With Clean Core (Using AEM):

  1. S/4 HANA triggers the BP Creation Event via Event Enablement Cockpit.
  2. AEM captures the events and routes it to all the subscribers.
  3. Subscribers (CPI, CAP apps, external systems) performs the required logic without modifying the core system.

No enhancement. No code in the core. Just events and clean extensions.

Common Use Cases Where AEM Drives Clean Core

  • Customer/Vendor Create in S/4HANA → Event to AEM → Update CRM/External apps.
  • Purchase Order Created → Event routed via AEM → Notify suppliers via external systems.
  • Material Master Update → Trigger downstream analytics apps or warehouse systems.

 Building Blocks of a Clean Core Event Strategy

1. Enable Eventing in Source System

    • Use Event Enablement Cockpit in S/4HANA (Cloud or Private Edition).

Within the SAP Application layer, where various types of event triggers are captured, these triggers can originate from the standard SAP mechanisms/ processes like Business Objects Repository(BOR) Event, Change Documents (CDHDR/ CDPOS), BTE(Business Transaction Event), IDOC Creation, Output Determination routines, and RAP based Event Triggers.

     

2. Route Event to AEM

    • Configure the required events in SAP S/4 to Publish Events to SAP Event Mesh/ AEM
    • Do the proper topic configurations and ensure secure connectivity.

3. Integrate with AEM

    • Use AMQP 1.0 protocol or SAP Event Mesh/ Advance Event Mesh Adapter in Integration Suite.

  1. Design Reusable Consumers
    • Keep business logic in SAP BTP (CAP, CPI, etc.).
    • Use topic naming standards (e.g., sap/s4/customer/created).

  2. Govern Events
    • Maintain versioning, documentation, and routing rules in AEM.


       

 Combine AEM with SAP Integration Suite or APIM

AEM becomes even more powerful when used alongside SAP Integration Suite:

  • Route events from AEM to CPI flows for orchestrations or APIM for Just Routing.
  • Use Process Integration for sync calls only where truly needed.

Summary

In SAP S/4 HANA, achieving Clean Core is no longer an optional choice, it’s a foundational strategy for designing scalable, maintainable, and future ready enterprise landscapes. This blogs explored how the SAP AEM empowers the organizations to adopt event driven architecture(EDA) that supports the Clean Core Principle by:

  • Decoupling the Core: Separating the custom logic, integrations, and extensions from the S/4HANA core using publish-subscribe event models.
  • Enabling Side-by-Side Extensibility: Leveraging SAP BTP and AEM to develop external applications and microservices without modifying the digital core.
  • Ensuring Upgrade Agility: Keeping the S/4 core untouched allows smooth upgrades with minimal regression testing.
  • Scaling Across Hybrid Landscapes: Distributing business events asynchronously to multiple consumers (on-premises and cloud) with minimal configuration overhead.

 Conclusion

Embracing SAP Advanced Event Mesh as the foundation of your integration and extension strategy ensures that you're not only building for the present, but also for the future. With AEM, you unlock a Clean Core architecture that is:

✅Upgradable
✅Extensible
✅Decoupled
✅Scalable

The Clean Core is no longer a destination, it’s a design principle. And AEM is your first step on that journey.

entry.title: SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central - Business Rule Function Doesnot Work as Expected
entry.content:
Introduction :

This Blog is written with a motive to bring the Business Rule Functions working behavior with Document Generation to the notice of the Engineering Team

Details of the Issue : 

We had a requirement to display the Revised and Previous Basic Salary of the Employees in a Document Template during Increments . This requirement came as a part of Increment Automation in SuccessFactors which will save a lot of time of the HR's from manually preparing the Salary Revision Letters. Past Direct won't work for this scenario as we need to only highlight the Basic Salary Revision.

Upon Detailed Analysis, @sandhiyat2001  found that the business rule function Get amount from previous PCR Record will solve our requirement but it didn't solve our purpose either we had issues with using the function in Document Generation Template Mapping. During Document Generation, we received the Placeholder permission error when we already had admin rights (Full access to the compensation information portlet and Pay components).

The Same Rule works as expected when assigned to Job Information Base Object and doesn't work the same way in Document Generation.

All thanks to my lovely colleague @sandhiyat2001 for pointing this out!

Conclusion :

Engineering Team is required to introspect into this issue and make sure that Business rules work the same across all SAP SuccessFactors Features

entry.title: Understanding the impact offer approvals in your hiring process
entry.content:
In this article we will confirm the requirements for offer approvals in certain hiring processes with SuccessFactors Recruitment, Onboarding and Employee Central.

Recruitment to Manage Pending Hires to Employee Central

The offer approval is mandatory for this process, if you do not have an offer approval, they will not appear in Manage Pending Hires.

Recruitment to Onboarding to Manage Pending Hires to Employee Central

The offer approval is not mandatory for this process. 

However, if your internal hire onboarding process is as follows,  Recruitment to Manage Pending Hires to Employee Central to Onboarding.  Then you will need to have an offer approval.

entry.title: A Failed Attempt at Implementing an Organization-Level HRBP Enhancement via Integration Center
entry.content:
Today, I’d like to share a solution attempt for enhancing organization-level HRBP management in SuccessFactors via Integration Center — and why it ultimately fell short. This idea originated from a customer requirement to manage HRBPs at the department level (similar to how department heads are managed), rather than at the individual or position level.

1. Requirement

Many customers prefer to manage HRBPs by department instead of person or position.
In this model:

  • HRBPs are maintained only in department data, not in job relationships.
  • Any HRBP update (due to termination, transfer, etc.) should automatically affect all employees under that department.

2. Typical Use Case

Example: In the Finance Department, HRBPs differ by region:

  • Finance – USA → HRBP A
  • Finance – Germany → HRBP B
  • Finance – China → HRBP C

An employee’s HRBP should be determined based on their department and location.

3. Background

Currently, standard SuccessFactors does not support HRBP management at the organization level.
Key points:

  • HRBP data can only be maintained in position relationships and job relationships, with synchronization between these two tables.
  • Maintaining HRBPs at the organization (department) level is unsupported, and cannot be automatically synced to employees’ job relationship data.

4. Custom Integration Enhancement Solution

Process Overview

The enhancement was designed with the following steps:

Step 1 – Create a Custom MDF Object
Create a departmentHR MDF object as a child of the Department general object.

Field Type Note
externalCodeStringAuto-generated — concatenates relationshipType and HRBP user ID
cust_HRUserHRBP User ID
cust_LocationGeneric ObjectLocation

Step 2 – Output Integration Center Job
Export employee job data (empJob) including:

  • userId
  • effectiveDate
  • sequence
  • location
  • Calculated column: HRBP (derived from location + division in job info)

 

Step 3 – Input Integration Center Job
Import and update job relationship records for each job info record, based on the exported data.

5. Limitation

This approach fails in scenarios where HRBP changes are future-dated but employees have no corresponding future-dated job info record.

Example:

Job Info:

UserId EffectiveDate HRBP
Employee-A2023-01-01A
Employee-A2024-01-02B

Department Data:

Department EffectiveDate HRBP
Dept-A2020-01-01A
Dept-A2024-01-01B
Dept-A2025-01-01C

Result: C will not appear for Employee-A until they have a job info record effective after 2025-01-01. This happens because:

  • empJob’s effective date is not derived from department effective dates.
  • Department data is fetched as of the job info’s effective date.
  • The future effective department record cannot be retrieved from empJob.

6. Thoughts for Improvement

  1. API-based Enhancement

    • Use API queries to:
      • Retrieve all employees under the department.
      • Retrieve all effective department records.
    • Insert corresponding HRBP records into job info for any date range between department effective dates.

  2. Using Standard “Manage Mass Change”

    • In standard SF, HRIS can use the Manage Mass Change tool to update HRBPs quickly whenever they change — even though this is manual, not automated.

7. Closing Thoughts

While this solution didn’t achieve the desired automation, I hope it provides some insight and sparks discussion. I’d greatly appreciate any thoughts on:

  • Why organization-level HRBP management is not considered best practice in SuccessFactors
  • Whether there are better workarounds for this requirement

entry.title: Boosting HR Data Quality in SuccessFactors: The Three Pillars for Driving Employee Central Value
entry.content:
In today’s digital workplace, HR data is more than a set of records — it’s the foundation for every payroll run, workforce report, and talent decision. When that foundation is shaky, the ripple effects are immediate and costly: delayed processes, bad analytics, compliance risks, and loss of executive trust.

At SAP SuccessFactors, we see the strongest results when customers approach data quality as an ongoing discipline, not just an afterthought. In Employee Central, this discipline can be framed around three pillars — each supported by embedded tools and best practices.

Pillar 1: Ensure Valid Configuration

The quality of your data starts with the quality of your configuration. A poorly designed rule or unchecked setting can silently introduce errors that multiply over time.

 Key enablers in Employee Central:

  • Business Rule Scenarios – Replace outdated “basic” rule setup with guided, scenario-based creation that reduces misconfigurations, enforces supported objects, and makes it easier to see where each rule is used.
  • Configuration Validations – Built-in guardrails in the Business Configuration UI and Foundation Objects to prevent risky changes (e.g., making business keys mandatory, external codes of Foundation Objects read-only).
  • Check Tool – Over 80 automated checks for configuration and data consistency, helping you resolve issues before they surface in production.
  • Diagnostic Tool – Trace the exact workflow or employee data change, see which business rules triggered, who approved, and what happened behind the scenes - invaluable for troubleshooting.

When these controls are in place, you start from a position of stability, rather than firefighting downstream issues.

 

Pillar 2: Enforce Valid Master Data

Even with perfect configuration, data quality can break down at the point of entry if there are no safeguards. This pillar is about guiding HR teams, managers, and employees to enter data correctly the first time.

 Practical examples in Employee Central:

  • Built-in Validations – Stop users from deleting key objects still in use, entering impossible dates of birth, or saving malformed email addresses.
  • Field Criteria & Associations – Filter selections dynamically (e.g., only show cost centres valid for the chosen legal entity) to avoid mismatches.
  • Conditional Defaulting – Automatically populate values like pay group or probation period based on complex criteria, reducing manual input.
  • Business Rules with Messages – Trigger warnings, errors, or informational messages in real time to prevent incorrect data saves.
  • Four-Eyes Principle in Workflows – Ensure no one approves their own requests, supporting compliance and audit integrity.
  • Alerts & Notifications – Proactively flag upcoming events (work permit expiry, end of contract, probation period) so action is taken before deadlines occur.
  • Configurable Hire Templates – Tailor the hire process to role, country, or employment type, reducing irrelevant fields and errors.

By embedding these measures, organisations move from reactive clean-up to preventative design — a far more sustainable approach.

 

Pillar 3: Identify & Cleanse Master Data

No system is immune to errors. The third pillar is about detecting and correcting issues quickly before they cause broader disruption.

 Tools to support cleansing in Employee Central:

  • Admin Alerts – Real-time notifications for data inconsistencies, stalled workflows, or invalid role assignments.
  • Data Check Tool – Over 40 checks for employee records, from missing work permit details to duplicate emergency contacts or overlapping dependent timelines.
  • Quick Fixes – In certain cases, the system can auto-correct issues found by checks, turning a multi-hour cleanup into a one-click action.

Proactive monitoring here not only protects daily operations but also keeps analytics, reporting, and AI training datasets trustworthy.

 

From Reactive to Proactive Data Quality

The organisations that extract the most value from Employee Central treat data quality as a living process — continuously monitored, refined, and embedded into both system design and daily HR operations.

It’s not about running a “data cleanup project” once a year. It’s about having guardrails at configuration time, smart validations at data entry, and powerful diagnostics and alerts for when something does go wrong. This holistic approach turns HR data into a genuine business asset — reliable, compliant, and ready to power strategic decisions.

Further Resources
SAP provides extensive guidance, release updates, and best practices to help you adopt these capabilities, from Business Rule Scenario migration blogs to Check Tool documentation. Regularly reviewing these resources, and building them into your governance model,  ensures that your data quality program evolves alongside your business.

entry.title: How Talent Intelligence Hub Connects 8 SuccessFactors Capabilities
entry.content:
Hi Readers,

When most HR professionals hear "Talent Intelligence Hub," they immediately think Growth Portfolio and career development. While that's certainly TIH's crown jewel, but limiting your perspective to just career pathing is like using a smartphone only for making calls. You're missing most of its potential.

TIH is far more than a career development tool – it's the intelligent backbone that transforms your entire SuccessFactors ecosystem.

While Growth Portfolio showcases TIH's career pathing capabilities, the real magic happens when TIH integrates seamlessly with Performance Management, Recruiting, Learning, Employee Central, and Compensation. These integrations turn isolated HR processes into an intelligent, connected talent ecosystem where every module becomes smarter through shared skill intelligence.

Think of TIH not as another module, but as your talent data command center where skills, capabilities, and career insights flow across every touchpoint of the employee journey. When properly integrated, TIH transforms reactive HR processes into predictive, personalized talent experiences that drive real business outcomes.

Let’s explore how Talent Intelligence Hub interacts with major modules in SuccessFactors and transforms key people processes.

1. Performance Management and 360 Reviews

TIH supercharges performance processes by letting managers and peers rate skills directly in Performance forms and 360 Reviews. 

  • Average ratings in 360 Reviews dynamically update the proficiency level for each skill in an employee’s growth portfolio.
  • Skill and competency ratings feed directly into the growth portfolio, building a rich, evolving view of employee capabilities.

2. Career Development

Career growth becomes more strategic with TIH:

  • The Career Worksheet identifies readiness for future roles, pulling proficiency data from the Growth Portfolio.

  • Employees and managers can associate specific skills with development goals, ensuring development plans are tailored and actionable.

3. Succession Management

Building future-ready teams is easier:

  • Talent Search for successors includes powerful filters based on skills, competencies, and ratings from the Growth Portfolio.
  • This ensures succession decisions are grounded in real, validated capability data.

4. Continuous Performance Management

TIH leverages Continuous Performance Management (CPM) to infer skills and recommend development actions:

  • CPM recommendations, powered by AI, are automatically sourced into the employee’s growth portfolio.
  • This turns everyday feedback and activities into actionable talent insights.

5. Dynamic Teams

Organizations now form agile, project-based teams with confidence:

  • Dynamic team roles include descriptions and proficiencies needed — skills are rated and tracked per assignment.
  • Once assignments are completed, new skills and experiences are added to employee growth portfolios, ensuring continuous skill evolution.

6. Opportunity Marketplace

SAP’s Opportunity Marketplace connects gigs, projects, and stretch assignments with employee skills:

  • TIH powers assignment recommendations based on growth portfolio attributes.
  • Skill-based filtering makes matches relevant and useful.

7. People Analytics

TIH enriches analytics, giving managers and admins deep visibility:

  • Dashboards highlight attributes of direct reports, average proficiency levels, rating gaps, and more.
  • This enables targeted investment in learning and succession.

8. Recruiting

Even the hiring process benefits:

  • Candidate skills can be rated and commented on by interviewers, feeding into the TIH for future growth and suitability analysis.

 In Interview Central, competencies, skills and interview questions from the job requisition are pulled.

9. Learning

TIH is the bridge between learning and performance:

  • After course completion, skill proficiency ratings update automatically in the Growth Portfolio.
  • Employees can search for learning content by skill, and receive personalized recommendations shaped by their portfolios.

Organizations embracing TIH are positioned to develop agile, future-ready teams and empower employees on their career journeys. If you’re looking to maximize your SuccessFactors investment, integrating with the Talent Intelligence Hub is the smart next step!

If you're planning a TIH implementation, currently in the middle of one, or just trying to understand what this platform does beyond the marketing materials, my blog will help cut through the noise and focus on what really matters for a successful deployment.  The stuff that matters when you're in the middle of an implementation and need straight answers. I've consolidated the key learnings from multiple projects to give you the facts without the fluff, based on what I've seen work and what doesn't in practice. TIH - Key Learnings from Client Projects 

Thank you for taking the time to read.

entry.title: 🔗 Employee Central to Employee Central Payroll Integration Scenarios – A Technical Perspective
entry.content:
🌐️SuccessFactors EC to Employee Central Payroll Integration – Direct vs IAS-based Connectivity

👨‍💻About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

📌Introduction

When implementing Employee Central Payroll (ECP), connectivity between SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) and Payroll plays a vital role in ensuring smooth payroll processes and seamless employee experience.

There are two main scenarios for this connectivity:

  1. ⚡Direct Connectivity – EC communicates with ECP without Identity Authentication Service (IAS).

  2. 🔒IAS-enabled Connectivity – EC communicates with ECP via SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Authentication (IAS).

Both approaches are valid, and depending on customer security policies, infrastructure readiness, and implementation strategy, one or the other may be chosen.

🎯Key Functionalities Enabled Through EC ↔ ECP Connectivity

Once the integration between SuccessFactors EC and ECP is established, organizations can leverage the following key functionalities:

  • 🧾 Direct Payslip Access from EC – Employees can view their pay statements directly in the EC Payroll Information tab.

  • 🔄Real-time Data Access – Payroll data and reports from ECP are available in EC.

  • ⚡Support Package Level Visibility – Administrators can check the ECP Support Package (SP) level from the EC interface.

  • 🆙Request ECP Support Package Upgrades – Through EC Upgrade Center, admins can request support package updates for ECP.

  • 🔐Seamless Authentication and SSO – Depending on the architecture, employees enjoy single sign-on across EC and ECP.

🏗️ Architecture Scenarios

1️⃣Direct Connectivity (EC → ECP)

In this approach, the connection is established directly between EC and ECP without an additional identity layer.

   🌐 SuccessFactors EC
          │
          ▼
   🖥️ Employee Central Payroll (ECP)

✔️Highlights

  • Simpler connectivity model.

  • No additional identity provider configuration.

  • Suitable for rapid implementations.

⚠️Considerations

  • Authentication handled directly at ECP level.

  • Less flexible for future cloud identity expansions.

2️⃣Connectivity with IAS (EC → IAS → ECP)

In this approach, SAP IAS acts as the identity layer, managing authentication and providing enhanced security.

   🌐 SuccessFactors EC
          │
          ▼
   🔑 SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS)
          │
          ▼
   🖥️ Employee Central Payroll (ECP)

✔️Highlights

  • Centralized identity management.

  • Better alignment with SAP’s long-term cloud security strategy.

  • Easier integration with other SAP SaaS products.

⚠️Considerations

  • Requires additional configuration of IAS tenants.

  • Slightly more complex to implement initially.

⚙️Automation via Upgrade Center

SAP has simplified IAS setup for ECP through Upgrade Center automation in SuccessFactors:

  • Navigate to Admin Center → Upgrade Center.

  • Select Employee Central Payroll IAS Integration.

  • Choose “Learn More & Upgrade Now” to automate IAS enablement.

💡This eliminates multiple manual steps and ensures standardization across environments.

📊Comparison of Connectivity Approaches

🏷️ Criteria                                    ⚡ Direct Connectivity (EC → ECP)                                🔒 IAS-based Connectivity (EC → IAS → ECP)
Architecture Simplicity✅Simple, fewer components involved⚠️Slightly complex due to IAS layer
AuthenticationHandled directly by ECPCentralized in IAS (cloud standard)
Implementation SpeedFaster setup, minimal stepsRequires IAS tenant setup & configuration
Security & ComplianceBasic securityEnhanced security with SSO & centralized identity
Future-readinessLimited flexibility for integration with other cloud products🌍Recommended by SAP for long-term roadmap
Upgrade PathManual checks & upgradesSupported with Upgrade Center automation
Best Use CaseRapid go-live, smaller landscapesEnterprises with strong security requirements & multi-cloud strategy

🖼️ Key Implementation Screenshot

Figure : SuccessFactors Provisioning – SAML ACS URL Configuration
Below is an example screenshot from SuccessFactors Provisioning where we configure the Assertion Consumer Service (ACS) URL.

  • This ACS URL can either point to IAS (Identity Authentication Service) or directly to ECP (Employee Central Payroll), depending on the chosen architecture.

  • This configuration plays a crucial role in how authentication and single sign-on (SSO) are managed between EC and ECP.

Post updating the URL here, You can download the metadata from here and update it in IAS or ECP system as per the approach you follow. Follow the Step by Step documentation with screenshots from SAP for performing the scenarios. (Check Reference column at the end of the blog for links to SAP documentation).

👥User Provisioning & Authorization in ECP

For EC ↔ ECP integration to work (Direct or IAS-based), users must exist and have correct roles in ECP.

🔑Key Requirements

  • User Existence: Each employee must have a user master (SU01) in ECP.

  • Consistent IDs: EC, ECP, and IAS (if used) must share the same identifier (e.g., User ID).

  • Authorizations: Roles and objects required include:

    • Payroll Control Center (PCC) roles such as Process Manager / Process Modeler.

    • Authorization objects like P_PYT_CFG for payroll configuration.

    • Employee / Manager roles for payslip access.

    • Admin roles for payroll system configuration and SP upgrades.

📋Summary Table

Area Required Access
Employee Payslip AccessPayroll report / HR employee role
PCC FunctionsPCC roles (Process Manager, Modeler, etc.)
System ConfigurationAdmin roles for payroll setup & upgrades

👉Note: Authentication only confirms identity. Correct authorization is what finally enables payslip view and payroll activities in ECP.

✨Key Takeaways

  • Both Direct Connectivity and IAS-based Connectivity are supported.

  • Organizations with simpler landscapes or faster timelines may prefer Direct Connectivity.

  • Organizations with long-term cloud roadmaps and enhanced security needs should choose IAS-based Connectivity.

  • Upgrade Center automation makes IAS setup easier, reducing manual administrative work.

❓FAQs

Q1: Do I always need IAS for EC ↔ ECP integration?
➡️No. Direct connectivity is still supported, but IAS is recommended for cloud security and future readiness.

Q2: What’s the main difference in authentication between the two models?
➡️In direct connectivity, authentication is managed at ECP. In IAS model, authentication is centralized in IAS.

Q3: Can I request ECP Support Package (SP) upgrades via EC?
➡️Yes. Once connectivity is established, EC provides visibility into ECP SP levels and you can raise upgrade requests.

Q4: Is the IAS setup manual or automated?
➡️Initially, it was manual. Now, Upgrade Center automation simplifies the setup process significantly.

📚References

  • SAP Note 2253359 – Employee Central Payroll: Access to Payroll application (payslip)

  • SAP Help Documentation – SAP Cloud Identity Services – Identity Authentication for Employee Central Payroll Configuration Steps

  • SAP Help Documentation – Automation of SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) using Upgrade Center

entry.title: Post-Implementation Optimization Guide : Keeping Your SAP SuccessFactors Running Smoothly
entry.content:
Successfully implementing SAP SuccessFactors is a significant milestone, but it's just the beginning of your HR transformation journey. As business requirements evolve and your organization grows, your SuccessFactors environment needs regular attention to maintain optimal performance.

Why Post-Implementation Review Matters

Over time, even the best-configured systems can develop inefficiencies. Business processes change, new features are released, user needs evolve, and what worked perfectly at go-live may no longer serve your organization effectively. Without regular maintenance, organizations often experience:

  • Slower workflows
  • Outdated configurations
  • User frustration
  • Missed opportunities for automation

Key Areas to Monitor

System Performance Regular review of system configurations, integration health, and data quality ensures your platform continues running smoothly. This includes checking workflow efficiency, process performance, and overall system responsiveness.

Security and Compliance Role-based permissions, security settings, and compliance requirements need ongoing attention. Regular audits help identify potential vulnerabilities and ensure your system meets current regulatory standards.

Feature Utilization SAP regularly releases new features and enhancements. Many organizations miss opportunities to leverage capabilities they're already licensed for, simply because they haven't reviewed what's available since implementation.

User Experience Monitoring user adoption patterns, gathering feedback, and identifying pain points helps ensure your SuccessFactors investment continues delivering value to end users.

Practical Tools and Actions

Leverage SAP's Built-in Diagnostics. SAP provides a built-in Check Tool that automates system diagnostics, identifying configuration issues, security gaps, and performance bottlenecks. Regular use of this tool helps catch problems before they impact users.

HR Administrator Actions

  • Monitor user adoption metrics through system analytics
  • Review and clean up inactive user accounts and outdated role assignments
  • Audit workflow approvals for bottlenecks and delays
  • Validate data integrity across modules through standard reports

Business User Involvement

  • Gather regular feedback from managers and employees on system usability
  • Document new business requirements as they emerge
  • Identify manual workarounds that could be automated
  • Track which features are underutilized and why

Proactive Maintenance

  • Subscribe to SAP release notes to stay informed about new features
  • Establish regular configuration backup procedures
  • Monitor integration endpoints for data synchronization issues
  • Review and update security permissions quarterly

Regular Tasks for Partner Consultants

  • Instance Refresh: Refresh Preview and Development instances from Production to ensure consistent testing environments with current data
  • Data Cleanup: Remove inactive and outdated data, close previous year forms, and purge obsolete records
  • System Maintenance: Perform cache clearance and system optimization tasks
  • Job Monitoring: Check and monitor scheduled jobs to ensure all background processes are running successfully
  • Security Updates: Execute RBP refresh and role recertification processes
  • Integration Sync: Ensure HRIS synchronization and third-party system connectivity

Benefits of Regular Optimization

Organizations that regularly review and optimize their SuccessFactors environment typically see:

  • Improved system performance
  • Reduced support costs
  • Better user satisfaction
  • Stronger compliance

More importantly, they ensure their HR technology investment continues supporting business objectives as they evolve.

Moving Forward

Like a garden that requires regular tending to flourish, your SuccessFactors system needs continuous care and attention. Whether through internal resources or external expertise, ongoing optimization ensures your HR investment continues growing in value rather than becoming neglected and underperforming.

The key is establishing a regular cadence of review and improvement, ensuring your SuccessFactors investment continues delivering value long after the initial implementation.

entry.title: Unlocking MDF Power: A Practical User Case in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Today, I would like to share a custom MDF (Metadata Framework) use case that addresses a complex requirement related to Finance Cost Internal Control. While this specific requirement may not be applicable across all industries, the case demonstrates:

  • The capabilities of no-code MDF,

  • Its limitations and common workarounds,

  • A structured step-by-step problem-solving approach to achieve business outcomes through custom MDF design.

Business Requirement

Customer A has a strict internal cost control policy. The expense limit amount an employee can approve for direct reports (without Finance involvement) depends on Job Grade, Business Unit, and Expense Type, a workflow is needed if the data is needed to be updated based on if the limit guidance is exceeded.

Key UI Requirements

  1. A user-friendly form for employees to review costs and submit new applications with workflow.

  2. Expense limit guidelines and manager’s limit must be displayed for reference:

    • Expense guideline = based on Job Grade, Business Unit, and Expense Type.

    • Manager’s limit = retrieved from manager’s corresponding expense record.

    • Alerts:

      • Soft alert if Employee Limit > Guideline.

      • Error alert if Employee Limit > Manager Limit.

      • Error Alert if Employee select the item which is not available in manager's form.

  3. Expense amounts must be converted based on the source currency (multi-currency setup across business units).

  4. A unique record must exist per Business Unit and Expense Type.

  5. When viewing others’ expense data:

    • Only the latest record should be visible.

    • Some fields (e.g., attachments) must be hidden.

Workflow Requirements

  1. If Employee Limit <= Guideline and Employee Limit <= Manager Limit → Manager approval only.

  2. If Employee Limit > Guideline in any item → Manager + Finance Business Partner approval required.

  3. Records approved by Finance should not be flagged again as exceeding the guideline in the next application process.

  4. Finance approvers vary by applicant’s department.

  5. Both employees and managers (on behalf of direct reports) must be able to submit requests.

Requirement Analysis

RequirementCategoryReasoningHow to AchieveDifficulty (1–5)
User-friendly form & workflowMDF FormMultiple expense types, history & audit requiredEffective-dated parent-child MDF entity + MDF version history3
Unique record per BU + Expense TypeMDF FormPrevent duplicatesExternalCode = String Type + onSave rule to auto-generate key (UserID+BU+Type)4

Manager’s limitBusiness RuleDerived from manager’s recordLookup manager’s expense MDF form + auto-populate4
Currency conversionBusiness RuleMultinational setupLookup standard exchange rate table in SF3
Alerts for inappropriate limitsBusiness RulePrevent policy breachWarning & Error rules (onChange + onSave)2
Workflow conditionsWorkflow + RulesApproval logic across multiple itemsWorkflow rules with “Where” criteria5
Exclude already approved itemsWorkflow + RulesFinance-approved items shouldn’t re-trigger approvalAdd flag + exclude via “Where” condition5
Finance approver per departmentWorkflow + Dynamic RoleApprover varies by departmentCreate standalone dynamic role group2
Permissions for visibilityRBP + Field PermissionsControl record & field accessTarget populations + No Access permissions3

Technical Solution Overview

Form Design

  • Parent-child MDF entity for expense form.

  • Effective dating for history tracking.

  • A user can only maintain a record per one Expense Type and Business Unit.

Expense ApplicationApplicantuserreadAutomatically populated
Expense ApplicationGradepicklistreadAuto-populated from job info via business rule
Expense ApplicationBusiness UnitGOreadAuto-populated from job info via business rule
Expense ApplicationApplication Reasonstringwrite 
Expense ApplicationAttachmentattachmentNo Access 
Expense ItemExternal CodestringRead-Only Field in Objection DefinitionAuto-populated based on UserId, BU and Expense Type.
Expense ItemExpense TypepicklistwritePicklist is maintained by admin.

Expense ItemCurrencyGOreadSF have standard Currency MDF object.
Expense ItemExpense Limit (Guideline)numberRead-Only Field in Objection DefinitionAuto-populated Expense Limit(Guideline) trhough Lookup function based on Expense type, job grade and business unit. 
Expense ItemManager LimitnumberRead-Only Field in Objection DefinitionAuto-populated Line Manager’s limit trhough Lookup function.
Expense ItemEmployee LimitnumberWrite 
Expense ItemSpecial ApprovalpicklistRead-Only Field in UIFinance BP Maintain it as “Yes” for the records in which employee limit exceed the limit after it is approved

Business Rules

  1. Approval Workflow conditions: The condition section should evaluate every possible combination of scenarios.

  2. Auto-population of manager limit through Looking up MDF form 

  3. Currency conversion logic: The currency rate could vary per month according to the effective date)

  4. Alerts for expense type violations. Trigger error message if the selected item is not available in your manager's form.

  5. External Code Auto-Generation: For integration scenarios, always use String-type external codes with auto-generation onsave rule when fixed logic could be set up.

Limitations & Workarounds

  1. UI Layout for Parent-Child MDF

    • Grid layout not supported in Employee Profile for Parent-Child MDF.

    • Long scroll issue exists in Employee Profile if many child records exist, but grid form layout natively works in Manage Data.

  2. Pending Data Visibility

    • Pending records are not shown natively in Employee Profile.

    • However, they are visible in Manage Data with alerts an an expected even if only "view current" permission is given.

  3. Workflow Restriction

    • Workflows can only be attached at Parent Object level.

    • Requires complex conditions to evaluate all child records to trigger workflow. See KBA: 2839730 MDF Parent object triggering the wrong workflow based on the child record inserted

  4. Dynamic Role Limitation

    • Approvers cannot be directly derived from Department object.

    • Standalone dynamic roles must be created.

  5. Field Level Permission Gaps

    • Field-level permissions only respected in Parent Object, not Child. See KBA: 2303419 RBP Permission for MDF Composite Child Object does not respect Target Population for Field Level Overrides

  6. Read-Only Behavior Differences

     Manage Objection DefinitionBusiness Configuration UIFinal Behaviour
    "Special Approval" Field Attribute-Option1EditableRead-Onlyreadable in Employee Profile but editable in "Workflow Update"/"manage Data" portal.
    "Special Approval" Field Attribute-Option2Read-OnlyRead-OnlyReadable both in Employee Profile and "Workflow Update"/"manage Data" portal.

  7. MDF is userId-based (not personalExternalId).

    1. Sometimes it is not user-friendly when it is personal.

    2. Multiple Expense exist for concurrent employment.

Conclusion

This case highlights how SuccessFactors MDF can be extended to support complex Finance cost control policies. Despite its limitations, with the right design patterns and careful use of lookup tables, workflow rules, and permissions, MDF can achieve highly specific business requirements.

entry.title: Getting Ready for AI-Assisted Applicant Screening in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Getting Ready for AI-Assisted Applicant Screening in SAP SuccessFactors

Recruiting is one of the most time-consuming parts of HR. For many companies, every new job role attracts hundreds of CVs. Recruiters spend hours reading applications, hiring managers get frustrated waiting for shortlists, and candidates often feel lost in the process.

SAP SuccessFactors has introduced a new feature — AI-assisted applicant screening, powered by Joule — to make this easier. The idea is simple: the system can read applications, match skills to the job, and even rank candidates from best to least fit. This has the potential to change how recruiters work, but there is something important to understand.

This feature does not simply work out of the box. To get value from it, you first need to set up some important building blocks in your system.

What you need before enabling AI-assisted screening

Over the last few months of working with clients, I have seen that the success of AI-assisted screening depends on six key areas:

1. Recruiting Management (RCM)

This is the foundation. Without properly structured job requisitions, application templates, and candidate profiles, there is no data for AI to work on.

2. Job Profile Builder (JPB)

Job Profile Builder is where you define jobs, roles, competencies, and required skills. The better this is set up, the stronger the AI matching will be. Think of it as the dictionary that AI uses to understand your jobs.

3. Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH)

This is becoming more and more important. TIH provides a single skills framework across the system. When jobs and candidates speak the same “skills language,” the AI can make much better decisions about fit and ranking.

4. Joule with AI Units License

Joule is the intelligence layer inside SAP SuccessFactors. With the AI Units license, Joule can power features such as skills extraction, candidate-job matching, stack ranking, and even generating interview questions. Without Joule and the license, the feature cannot be enabled.

5. Role-Based Permissions (RBP)

Permissions are often overlooked. Recruiters and hiring managers need access to view AI insights, while system administrators need access to configure and monitor AI services.

6. Clean and consistent data

The simplest, but often the hardest step. If job descriptions are vague, or candidate data is incomplete, the AI will not give useful results. Clean data is the backbone of any successful AI implementation.

Why stack ranking makes a difference

The most useful feature of AI-assisted screening is stack ranking. This means applicants are automatically sorted from best fit to least fit based on the job requirements and the skills framework.

This helps in many ways:

  • Recruiters save time by not manually scanning hundreds of CVs.

  • Hiring managers get a clear shortlist and understand why certain candidates are ranked higher.

  • Every applicant is checked in the same way, which makes the process more consistent and fair.

  • Recruiters get more time to focus on meaningful conversations with candidates instead of repetitive screening tasks.

A real example from practice

One global technology company I worked with introduced AI-assisted screening for their campus hiring. They received thousands of applications for a single drive. Normally, this would take recruiters several weeks to manage.

With stack ranking enabled, the system automatically highlighted the most relevant candidates. The results:

  • Screening time reduced by 40 percent

  • Recruiters could finally spend more time engaging with students

  • Hiring managers felt the shortlist was of much higher quality

The company is now planning to extend this approach to experienced hiring as well.

Final thoughts

AI-assisted applicant screening in SAP SuccessFactors is not about replacing recruiters. It is about helping them focus on people, not paperwork.

But success depends on getting the basics right. Recruiting Management, Job Profile Builder, Talent Intelligence Hub, Joule with AI Units, Role-Based Permissions, and clean data — these are the real prerequisites.

Once these are in place, stack ranking can truly change the way hiring teams work — making recruitment faster, fairer, and more consistent.

entry.title: Complete Guide to Setting Up Story Reports in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Objective: Learn how to configure Story Reports in SAP SuccessFactors with step-by-step instructions, best practices, and troubleshooting tips.

Table of Contents:

  1. Introduction.
  2. Licensing Overview.
  3. Pre-Requisites for Story Reports.
  4. IPS Sync Configuration.
  5. Settings Role-Based Permissions for Story Report.
  6. Creating a Story Report
  7. Styling and Chart Configuration
  8. Common Issues and Fixes
  9. Conclusion and Community Tips

Introduction:

SAP SuccessFactors Story Reporting is a modern reporting solution that transforms traditional HR reporting into interactive, visual, and real-time analytics. It empowers users to create dynamic reports with rich visualizations.

Story reports are recommended to use due to their various benefits as visualized in the image below:

Licensing Overview:

  • Story Reporting is included with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central.
  •  However, Workforce Analytics (WFA) and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) require separate licenses.
  • Note that live payroll data reporting is not supported in Story Reports and may require third-party tools like Query Manager.

Pre-Requisites for Story Reports:

  • Go to Upgrade Center and activate 'Stories in People Analytics'.
  • Configure Identity Authentication Service (IAS) and Identity Provisioning Service (IPS).
  • Ensure user sync from SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) via IPS.

IPS Sync Configuration:

  • To perform the IPS Sync, navigate to “Target Systems” to enable the newly configured SAP Analytics Cloud tenant.
    • Select the target system à select the “Edit icon” à  choose “Enable” and on the confirmation pop-up message that appears, choose “OK”.  The status of the tenant changes to “Enabled”. 
    • Navigate to “Source Systems” and select your source “SAP SuccessFactors tenant”.
    • Go to --> Jobs tab --> Read Job type à choose --> Run Now.
    • You can track the progress of the read job from Job Logs.
    • When the read job is completed, the user sync from SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite to SAP Analytics Cloud is completed.

Settings RBP for Story Report:

  •    Create Story: Full access to create, edit, share and manage reports.
  • Story Admin: Manage all Story Reports and access 'All Reports' tab

  • Manage Integration Tools → Allow Admin to Access ‘OData API through Basic Authentication’
  • Manage User → Data Access: User (Ensure user data visibility)

Developing a Story report:

  1. Selecting a database: Below I have selected ‘Job information’ and ‘Personal Information’ as a combination and selected the columns I need.
  2. Click on the ‘save’ on top of left corner and once done selecting the columns you need to click ‘Finish’ on bottom right corner of the screen.
  3. In the below image, I have dragged ‘Job Information’ and ‘Personal Information’, In personal information, I have selected ‘Gender’ to include the field in my report.

As “Job Information and Personal information” are effective dated entities, system will ask the ‘start date’ or ‘effective date’ from which you want the data to be reflected in the report.

Naming the database. Here, I have kept the database name as ‘Job Information’.

Once the database is saved system will redirect you to the below screen. You can ‘Insert’ and drag & drop title in the below screen:

Here, on the right side of the screen, we have 2 sections, Builder – is for configurational use and Styling – where cosmetics change can be done for respective charts.

Builder sections: Below is an overview sections available in Builder to use while developing your story report.

  • Here we have data source names, in charts we have various options to select from, as per requirement.
  • Below I have selected a “Bar/Column” chart where I can select its orientation.
  • Then we have measures and dimensions which I have explained below in details.

To use various charts, we need to define ‘Measure’ and ‘Dimensions’. Which are important to build a story report.

  1. Measure: A measure is a quantitative value that you can perform calculations on, such as sums, averages, counts, or percentages.
    • Examples: Number of employees, Average performance rating, Total compensation, Headcount.
    • Usage: Measures are typically used in charts and tables to show trends, comparisons, or aggregations.
  2. Dimension: A dimension is a qualitative attribute used to categorize or group data. It provides context for measures. 

    Styling: In styling we have various features available as highlighted in left side of the below image. Widgets and legends are basic and most use features in styling section.

    • Widgets – where you can customize background colour, borders – style, width etc
    • Legends- where name of the dimensions are displayed, you can decide where to place your legend with options as – above, below and beside charts.

    Configuring a simple chart: Below, I have created a Bar/column chart, which is vertical in orientation. Measure is ‘Count’ (Employee count) and dimension is ‘Gender’. Colour for the bar/column chart can also be customised as per requirement. In the example, the instance is using 4 genders – Male(M), Female(F), undeclared(D)and unknown(U)

Common Issues and Fixes:

  1. For a user to be able to create Story Reports, their user information must be successfully synchronized to the SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) instance (as discussed earlier in the blog) and be assigned the appropriate RBP access. When this does NOT occur, the user is unable to create a new Story report or when creating a new story report, the webpage is stuck in a blank loading screen, or errors are displayed.
  2. Troubleshooting common issues via check tool: 
    1. SACDuplicateEmailValidationCheck:  
      • Purpose: This check identifies duplicate or unmapped email addresses in the system that are not linked to any user configured for Stories in People Analytics.
      • Email addresses are the primary key for user identification in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC).
      • Duplicate or unmapped emails can cause login failures, reporting issues, or data inconsistencies in People Analytics.
    2. SACUserValidationCheckWithQuickFix
      1. Purpose: This check validates whether a user is correctly configured for Stories in People Analytics and offers a Quick Fix option if issues are detected.
      2. Ensures that users have the correct roles, permissions, and configurations to access Stories in People Analytics.
      3. Reduces dependency on manual troubleshooting by providing automated fixes.
    3. SACUserValidationCheck
      1. Purpose: This check verifies that a user record exists for Stories in People Analytics.
      2. Confirms that the user is present in the system, which is the first step before assigning roles or permissions.
      3. Prevents errors when granting access to People Analytics features.
         

    4. SAC connection error: In Check Tool when checked if the user exists in SAC and can see below error:

      1. The availability of the selected user couldn’t be confirmed for People Analytics, because of a connection error.
      2. To fix this we need to "Refresh SF Live Connection" and “x509 certificates” from Provisioning under "Configurations for Stories in People Analytics".

Conclusion:

Following these steps ensures a successful setup of Story Reports in SAP SuccessFactors. Share your experiences and tips in the comments to help others in the community.

entry.title: Use Employment Differentiator for Translation Limitation on People Profile and Spotlight Header
entry.content:
From customer implementation, we observe that the language translation on the spotlight header would stay in default language English instead of the expected translation version (f.e. French) by Language switch via user Settings.  Know issue was reported by the SAP Note below.

2648773 - Position Title and Department and Division are shown in English on Employee Profile header - Employee Profile

First, the French Translation has maintained in the Globe context menu for the Position. From the screenshots below, after switch the user language to French,  the translation for these Job and Org fields are displayed properly in Full Spotlight "Organization" Category Card.  However, the same French translation could not be synced to the Spotlight Header or Full Profile Header part where they are still displayed in English.

Secondarily, these Organization and Job Information fields displayed on Spotlight and Header Areas are coded with no feasibility to customize. 

  

 

As a workaround, we could introduce to use Employment Differentiator.  This differentiators function provides flexibility to display defined or customized three fields from JobInfo for all users no matter whether the user has multiple employments or not. You don't need to have prerequisite like multiple employments, concurrent employments, global assignment etc. This could be considered as "An Addition" for Customization. 

In my practice below to display French version of Division, Department and Job Classification in Spotlight and Full Profile Header. In general, we need to create an Employment Differentiator object in Manage Data. An Employment Differentiator allow maximum 3 custom fields by design. We can leverage these 3 custom fields to link to standard or custom fields from Job Information Model HRIS Elements (ONLY). Then, the values (picklist configured for HRIS elements) can be displayed accordingly by this Employment Differentiator. Here comes the key configuration steps: 

Step 1 - Create Picklist for "JobClass_FR", "Division_FR", and "Dept_FR" respectively. Set these 3 picklist values directly as the French version of translation (These can be fetched from Manage Position). 

Step 2 - In Business Configuration, create custom-string for "Division FR", "Dept FR" and "Job Class FR" and set the picklist we configuration in Step 1 to the object respectively. 

Step 3 - Set Permission Roles for the custom-strings created in Step 2 for both System Admin and Employee Self Service. The proper role settings make sure both New Hire and Existing Employee will not miss to select the value defined in picklist as mandatory. 

This is important to remember that If the value used for the differentiator is not available in the current Job Information record, the value will not be displayed in People Profile.

Step 4 - To adopt Employment Differentiator, assignmentDisplayHeader should be enabled in Business Configuration -> Employee Profile -> Standard. 

In addition, please make sure RBP settings are configured for both System Admin and Employee Self Service to View/Edit Employee Data -> Employee Profile -> ASSIGNMENTDISPLAYHEADER.

Step 5 - Set up the Employment Differentiator object to connect the dots. It is named "Org Job FR" in my practice and its 3 custom fields point to the 3 custom-string created in Step 2. Jobinfo is only the supported HRIS element reference by design.

Step 6 - To Switch ON the Employment Differentiator, go to Configuration Latest People Profile -> General Settings -> Choose the Name created in Step 5 from the dropdown list of Choose Employment Differentiator.  Click the Save button.

Do not forget to Refresh Assignment Header and Refresh General Display Name from the Company System and Logo Settings to activate it.  After both HRIS Sync jobs are Completed from Scheduled Job Monitoring, it's time to check the final result. 

Step 7 - Final Check. The French Version can be displayed on header no matter which language setting is selected. 

Last but not least, Employment Differentiator could be used not only for translation workaround, but for dispalying any additional job information as well.

More details could be referred in the following SAP Help link. 

Adding Employment Differentiators To Indicate Multiple Employments

2786331 - Employee Central - Employment Differentiators Indicator

Thanks for your reading and hope this blog is helpful!

entry.title: Enhancing Successfactors Alert Message With Images Through HTML
entry.content:
Scenario

With the scenario as ours in consideration where the business required an image and a footer on already existing birthday alert message for users company wide.

The scenarios might differ company wise or client wise but the very basic method or process of fulfilling this requirement remains the same widely.

Alert Message Configuration 

Here we will be discussing the pre-requisite and configurations required for a header and a footer for our system triggered alert message and possible issues along with their solutions that we might face post alert trigger.

Pre - Requisites

  • We should have admin rights on Successfactors preferably Manage Data and Alert Message permissions.
  • We should have a One Drive and Outlook access for uploading our header and footer and validating our email alert respectively.
  • Thirdly, we shall be able to host or upload the images which we want to use as a header and a footer for our alert message (in our case we have uploaded it on a One Drive folder) as we will be using the One Drive link of that picture in our HTML code.
  • We can also host the images online through free available tools and then use that link in our html.

Configuration 

  • Create an alert message as per your message content.
  • Use the below mentioned html code for the header/footer section where you want the pictures to appear in the alert message as per attached image.


<html>
<body>
<h2></h2>
<img src="Use The Link Within These Inverted Commas Mentioned In The Third Point Under Pre-Requisites Heading" width="100" height="50">
</body>
</html>​
  • Adjust the width and height as per your requirement.
  • Please note that if you want to include both header and footer (like in our case), the mentioned html code must be used separately first in the header area (where you want your header to appear) and then in the footer section (where you want your footer to appear) with the width/height adjustments as per the requirements.
  • We can also use below code for center alignment of the images,
<h2></h2>
<div style="text-align: center;">
<img src="Use The Link Within These Inverted Commas Mentioned In The Third Point Under Pre-Requisites Heading" width="500" height="333">
</div>​
  • Now initiate the alert message and check your email for your required header and footer.

Incase we receive an email with below attached error in your header/footer or in an image. The possible reasons might be,

  1. We might have made a mistake in copying the link.
  2. The image might have been removed from the folder you uploaded on.
    If you are sure about the above two points then the most probable reason is that,
  3. Your organization has blocked the https images on your email. In this case you can co-ordinate with your internal services team or follow the below Microsoft blog for resolution.
    The Linked image cannot be displayed error - Outlook | Microsoft Learn
  4. Get the https images allowed for your organization and you will start receiving the email with the recent made changes. 

Conclusion

Concluding, we can use different html tags to enhance the alert triggers that are being initiated from SuccessFactors. With a little tweaking and understanding of html tags we can actually cater the business requirements that can standout.

entry.title: Enhancing Background Information Integration Across Recruiting, Onboarding, and Employee Central
entry.content:
Introduction

Today, I would like to share a solution that addresses a common challenge in background information integration (e.g., outside work experience, education, languages, certificates, and more) across SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting, Onboarding, and Employee Central (EC).

By introducing both the SAP standard design and an enhanced solution I implemented, I aim to highlight:

  • The limitations of the current standard design
  • Why SAP should consider improving this area
  • How organizations can achieve a low-cost enhancement for a more seamless process

Background

A customer required a seamless experience for collecting candidate background information. Ideally, the process should follow these steps:

  1. Application Stage: Candidates provide background information (outside work experience, education, language proficiency, and certificates) when submitting a job application.
  2. Onboarding Stage: Once an offer is accepted, candidates can review and update their data in Onboarding and add additional background information which is not required to fill in recruiting phase (e.g., memberships).
  3. Employee Central Integration: This background data should flow automatically and consistently into SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC).
  4. Employee Self-Service (ESS): Background information should remain editable via EC workflows after hiring.

Unfortunately, this seemingly simple and logical process is not fully supported in the standard SuccessFactors design due to the following limitations:

  1. Background elements in the candidate profile can only be synchronized directly to the Employee Profile without through onboarding phase. Please refer to KBA: 2233525 - How is the system working with sm-mapping? - Recruiting Management.
  2. Standard background elements cannot be configured in the New Hire Data Collection template. This means background data cannot be reviewed or updated during the Onboarding phase.
  3. EC workflows cannot be configured for standard background elements. Typically, MDF-based background information is required in order to enable workflows.  Please refer to KBA: 2829360 - Workflows and Business Rules - Are they Supported for EP Portlets?

Workaround

To enable ESS workflows and Onboarding Data Collection, it is recommended to use MDF-based background information.   The MDF-based background objects should be configured to mirror the field settings of the standard background elements. This ensures consistency of data structures across modules.   To maintain alignment between the two, use Integration Center to perform a one-way synchronization from MDF-based background information to the standard background elements.

However, this introduces a new challenge:
How can we keep the standard background information blocks (required by Talent Development modules) aligned with the MDF-based data? The key difficulties are:

  1. Automatic synchronization of MDF data into background information blocks.
  2. Avoiding duplicate entries: Each background record is uniquely identified by backgroundElementId, which is auto-generated by the system. If not matched, the system treats incoming records as new ones. Since Integration Center jobs cannot capture responses (as in CSV imports), careful design is required to prevent duplicate records.

Solution

The solution involves using Integration Center to auto-sync MDF-based background information into Employee Profile (EP) background elements for new hires. This is a one-time sync executed after the employee becomes an EC user.

 

Key Design Points

  • Timing of Integration

    • Synchronization should occur only after Manage Pending Hire is completed and the Employee Conversion job has run. At this point, the Employee Profile is active and actionable.
    • Integration criteria should be based on the OnboardingHireStatus in the Process Table, combined with a recent hire date filter (e.g., within the past week). This ensures only newly hired employees are included.

 

  • Handling Multiple Records (e.g., Education)

    • When working with multiple education records, the challenge is that Integration Center cannot navigate from a child entity back to the parent object.
    • To address this, a custom user field is created to automatically populate the new hire’s User ID using an onsave Business Rule.
    • With this field in place, the integration can navigate from the child entity (e.g., Education) to the User/ONB2Process table, applying the required filters.

  • Removed Duplicated Background Info via Provisioning Job

    • Enable Provisioning Job to remove the duplicated background info record which is inserted by API or Integration Center accidentally and unexpected. Please refer to KBA: 2790234 - Delete Duplicate Background Data

Conclusion

While the standard SAP SuccessFactors design does not currently provide a seamless end-to-end flow for background information, this MDF-based enhancement with Integration Center offers a practical, low-cost workaround.
It enables:

  • A smoother transition of data across Recruiting, Onboarding, and Employee Central
  • The ability for employees to manage and update their background information through ESS workflows
  • Continued support for Talent Development modules by keeping standard background blocks aligned This solution demonstrates how thoughtful enhancements can bridge gaps in the current design and deliver the seamless user experience customers expect.
